SAINT JOHN’S UNIVERSITY
COLLEGEVILLE, MINNESOTA
PRESIDENT
Senator Eugene J. McCarthy
Senace
Washington, D.C.
March 8, 1967
Dear Senator McCarthy:
As you know, President Johnson has recently proposed new legislation
for educational broadcasting to be known as the Public Television Act
of 1967. The Administration bill should be introduced very shortly
by Senator Magnuson and Representative Harley Staggers.
This bill is of particular interest to us, at St. John’s, because for
the first time educational radio has been included in federal legislation
designed to encourage educational broadcasting.
Having realized the potential of educational radio and the contribution
it can make in our area, both in terms of providing instructional and
educational programs as well as its ability to present cultural and fine
arts programming, we have established a high power FM educational station
here in Collegeville and we have applied to the F.C.C. for a second
transmitter in the Minneapolis and St. Paul area.
Our studies indicate that educational radio is as effective as television
and often times a more effective medium for the presentation of this type
of programming, while offering a considerably more economical basis of
operation to the small college.
In addition to our broadcasting efforts at St. John's, we have, during
the past several months, been in discussion with the Minnesota Private
Colleges, concerned with the need for a non-commercial FM educational
radio service for the state. The conclusions drawn at these meetings
indicate that the demands of our contemporary society require educational
institutions to be more than storehouses of accumulated knowledge; that
today's university must function actively as a contributing member of
the society that sustains it, sharing its resources and experience with
the community generally.
